content: No. It is not accurate to say that younger people are less likely to volunteer during disasters because they are selfish or self-centered. In fact, younger people have consistently shown a desire to engage in volunteering and community service. They are often passionate about social causes, and many are actively involved in volunteer work. There may be various reasons why younger people might not volunteer during a disaster, such as a lack of experience or knowledge about disaster relief, scheduling conflicts due to school or work, or geographical distances from the affected areas. However, it is important to recognize that people of all ages and backgrounds can make meaningful contributions to disaster relief efforts, and each individual's participation should be valued based on their abilities, interests, and circumstances.
